problem: Think step by step and answer in short: For all positive integers $n$, the $n$th triangular number $T_n$ is defined as $T_n = 1+2+3+ \cdots + n$. What is the greatest possible value of the greatest common divisor of $4T_n$ and $n-1$?
solution: By the arithmetic series formula, $T_n = \frac{n(n+1)}{2}$, so $4T_n = 2n(n+1) = 2n^2 + 2n$. By the Euclidean algorithm, \begin{align*}\text{gcd}\,(2n^2 + 2n, n-1) &= \text{gcd}\,(2n^2 + 2n - (n-1) \times 2n, n-1) \\ &= \text{gcd}\,(4n, n - 1) \\ &= \text{gcd}\,(4n - 4(n-1) , n-1) \\ &= \text{gcd}\,(4, n -1) \le \boxed{4}.\end{align*} For example, this is true for $n = 5$.
pred:
We can rewrite $T_n$ as $T_n = \frac{n(n+1)}{2}$. Therefore, $4T_n = 2n(n+1)$. We want to find the greatest common divisor of $2n(n+1)$ and $n-1$. 

We can use the Euclidean algorithm to find the greatest common divisor. 

\begin{align*}
\text{gcd}(2n(n+1), n-1) &= \text{gcd}(n-1, 2n(n+1) - (n-1)(2n)) \\
&= \text{gcd}(n-1, 2n(n+1) - 2n(n-1)) \\
&= \text{gcd}(n-1, 2n) \\
&= \text{gcd}(n-1, 2n - 2(n-1)) \\
&= \text{gcd}(n-1, 2) \\
\end{align*}

Since $n$ is a positive integer, $n-1$ is always odd. Therefore, the greatest common divisor of $2n(n+1)$ and $n-1$ is $\boxed{2}$.
